articles.headline: Professional Money Fund Is Closed by Putnam
articles.snippet: Putnam Investments, one of the oldest names in the mutual fund industry, said it was liquidating a $12.3 billion money market fund.
articles.abstract: Putnam Investments, one of the oldest names in the mutual fund industry, said it was liquidating a $12.3 billion money market fund.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the second time in a week, a multibillion-dollar money market fund has been forced to take extraordinary steps to deal with sudden cash withdrawals by nervous institutional investors.

articles.headline: A Bid to Curb Profit Gambit as Banks Fall
articles.snippet: A backlash against short sellers has begun, with regulators in the U.S. and Britain tightening rules and authorities in New York intensifying investigations.
articles.abstract: A backlash against short sellers has begun, with regulators in the U.S. and Britain tightening rules and authorities in New York intensifying investigations.
articles.lead_paragraph: Traders who have sought to profit from the financial crisis by betting against bank stocks were attacked on two continents on Thursday.
articles.byline: By Vikas Bajaj and Jonathan D. Glater

articles.headline: Uproar Over German Bank’s Payout to Lehman
articles.snippet: As the rest of the financial community was scrambling to get its money out, a government-owned German lender gave Lehman Brothers 300 million euros on the same day it filed for bankruptcy.
articles.abstract: As the rest of the financial community was scrambling to get its money out, a government-owned German lender gave Lehman Brothers 300 million euros on the same day it filed for bankruptcy.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN  As the rest of the financial community was scrambling to get its money out, a government-owned German lender gave Lehman Brothers what might be called a parting shot in the arm, transferring 300 million euros to the investment bank on the same day it filed for bankruptcy.

articles.headline: Drug Label, Maimed Patient and Crucial Test for Justices
articles.snippet: At issue is whether plaintiffs have the right to sue when the products that hurt them had met federal standards.

articles.lead_paragraph: MARSHFIELD, Vt.  When Diana Levine starts talking about her rock ’n’ roll days, she plays a little air guitar, mimicking the way she used to handle her electric bass in bands like the Re-Bops and Duke and the Detours. But Ms. Levine is missing much of her right arm, which was amputated below the elbow after a medical disaster.

articles.headline: War and Drought Threaten Afghan Food Supply
articles.snippet: More than a quarter of the population may face a harsh winter as a result of a pitiable harvest this year.
articles.abstract: More than a quarter of the population may face a harsh winter as a result of a pitiable harvest this year.
articles.lead_paragraph: YAKOWLANG, Afghanistan  A pitiable harvest this year has left small farmers all over central and northern Afghanistan facing hunger, and aid officials are warning of an acute food shortage this winter for nine million Afghans, more than a quarter of the population.

articles.headline: Vast Bailout by U.S. Proposed in Bid to Stem Financial Crisis
articles.snippet: Treasury and Fed officials were discussing with leaders in Congress a plan for the government to buy up distressed mortgages.
articles.abstract: Treasury and Fed officials were discussing with leaders in Congress a plan for the government to buy up distressed mortgages.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The head of the Treasury and the Federal Reserve began discussions on Thursday with Congressional leaders on what could become the biggest bailout in United States history.

articles.headline: The Pain of Selling a Home for Less Than the Loan
articles.snippet: Instead of writing off an unpaid portion of a mortgage debt, banks want homeowners to sign a note promising to pay some or all of the balance due after the home is sold.
articles.abstract: Instead of writing off an unpaid portion of a mortgage debt, banks want homeowners to sign a note promising to pay some or all of the balance due after the home is sold.
articles.lead_paragraph: Many Americans are discovering an unfortunate twist to the housing crisis: even after selling a home and moving away, they might have to keep paying on it for years, even decades.
